list.item: Boys' dormitory comes to an end

p.del: in Washington too - but it will be different. I am anxious to know what you think of my staying here another year too. Perhaps I ought not - but on the other hand there seem to be about as many reasons for as against. Things do get so muddled up sometimes it seems hard to know just what is the thing to do. Well to return to a recital of events -

div1.p:
Lapse of several hours and now 6:50 p.m. The last bell for B.Y. has rung & we are all easily seated around the fire & not B.Y. - ing thank goodness - It is
nice not to have to go out again tonight - and B.Y. does get tiresome to us all - The little boys are gone now that stayed with Mrs. Profitt & Mr. C. - One got mad & left - another had to go home & help get things ready for the planting and the third got a job on Little River - $2.50 a day & about ten years old at that. Their house is cold so Evelyn had them bath here (Mr. C. & Mrs. P.) for supper & to stay all night - and for dinner again - Tom usually spends his birthday with Mr. C. so of course he was here too - Then at Sunday School this morning Evelyn asked them all to come up here and sing in the p.m. - They often do
that at the church - but it was too cold today - So about 1:30 they began arriving & I think there must have been fifteen or twenty here altogether - stayed until four - Sang hymns & had some phonograph records - They all behaved very quietly & nicely too.

After they left Evelyn & I went down the road with Josie Trentham (from the hotel) about a mile or so & met the girls who had walked about half way up here over the worst part & were met by Mr. C. with Dan & the buggy -

It was a gorgeous afternoon though this morning was snowy & threatening & the ground all white again. The mountains in the distance which are higher are white - & glistening in the sunlight - each tree seems to stand out by itself a white specter as it were - The ground was frozen hard & full of ruts & uneven places which made the walking very difficult in spots. The air so cold that it made your face tingle - but walking is warm work so we enjoyed it. Every little while we spoke of how cold the girls - Abbie & Evelyn - must be but we found out later that our sympathy was quite wasted for their seven mile tramp had warmed them up so thoroughly that the ride of the remaining seven did not affect their temprature!

p.del: We were all so hungry again tonight & had another
